segments.text: At A&M, man, no, if you belong to fraternity, I remember back in there, this Preacher Durst that became vice president of Brown and Root, he was a fraternity man.
And the summer vacation between my freshman year and sophomore year, Preacher had gotten a letter from Dr. Bazell.
saying that they were clamping down on student activities, hazing, and fraternities.
They knew fraternities existed at A&M, but they didn't have enough proof.
But if they found out that a student was a fraternity man, they were going to expel him.
That's right.
So a preacher told me about it that summer.
He said, we've been sent this letter.
And if any of us belong to fraternities, when we go back, if they find it out, we expect to be expelled.
Well, he wasn't expelled.
But my captain was a good officer.
He's dead and gone.
But he was a good officer, a swell person.
And so was the major of the cavalry that year.
My freshman year, I cleaned up his room.
Old Dusty Dodson from Amarillo, Texas.
And he was a good major.
They were all good men.
I didn't know a single one that wasn't an outstanding individual.
And as far as I was concerned, they did a lot of good for Texas A&M.
But we suspended those
football players.
We suspended them until the second semester, I believe, of the following year.
Of course, the second semester of that year was about over, so they were allowed to finish that semester.
But they were not going to be allowed to come back in until the second semester of the following year.
But they came back in in September of that year.
To play football.
The chairman of the board.
And I don't know who else.
And now you suspect.
And here was another name that was read off, too.
And he was, well, anyhow.
The ex-students association of Texas A&M.
I just wondered, too, how long they were operating under the TTs.
That's just my idea.
I know that one of the executive directors was T.T.
Whether his followers were or not, I wouldn't know.
I care less.
It really doesn't matter because, as I said, they were all good men.
And whatever they did, they did it for A&M, and I don't believe you could have gotten a truer Aggie anywhere than those fellows.
Now, we've talked about a lot of changes in vet medicine from the 1930s to the 1960s.
There must have been something that I've missed that we should talk about.
Do you have any ideas about that?
I mean, I'm certainly no expert in veterinary science, that's for sure.
No, the big thing is that we have improved.
And I think now that the College of Veterinary Medicine at A&M is an outstanding institution, I think it is head and shoulders.
Well, there is no comparison now to what we were in the 30s.
We were nothing in the 30s.
Absolutely.
And how we ever got the board of directors to put on a big building program for us
In 1931, when we had but one graduate in 1930, must have been politics.
Here they built it where civil engineering is now.
All of that sprang up.
And before that, we just had some shacks.
We had Francis Hall, of course, but it was terribly run down and nothing in it except in physiology and pharmacology.
Nothing.
But we've spread out all over creation now and have, I don't know, 150 men on the staff, not to mention technical help galore.
They have three or four or five in veterinary anatomy.
When I was crying for all the years I was in there for one person and didn't get that until 15 years later.
No.
There's no comparison.
As a final question, then, I'd like to ask you to evaluate your own career.
I wouldn't know how to evaluate it.
I work like a fool, and that's about all I can say.
But I'm proud of what I did.
I gave them something in both departments to build on.
You were appreciated.
When we were down and out, then I was there in the breach.
And we built from there.
And we certainly had nothing when I went in.
Well, were there things during your about 30 years that you wanted?

35 years that you wanted to do, which you just couldn't accomplish, not necessarily because of your own self, but because of other outside circumstances or other shortcomings, especially in your own department?
Well, I'd like to have built a department up to where we could have had a big research program
We could have had 10 or 12 staff members and so on.
But the money wasn't there.
I don't know.
To begin with, I was never too sold on a person teaching and researching.
I wasn't too sold on that.
I thought, if you're going to teach what teach, and if you're going to research, do that.
give all of your time to one or the other.
Because as I could see it then, you needed all of the time you had and more to prepare yourself for teaching.
To do all of the research, the reading in research and so on, and keep up with your field, that would leave very little time for any research.
You couldn't keep your mind, unless you were given
A third of your time where you had nothing else to do but research.
If you had to carry research along with your teaching, one or the other is going to suffer.
I still think that.
Or you are like some of the professors I've had who were doing research.
They get you off on their research project, and that's about all they know to talk about.
Uh, you mean old pine tree so-and-so?
Are you talking about Dr. Old Pine Tree So-and-So?
That's about all he talked in his course on the pine tree because he did his PhD on the life cycle of the pine.
I know what you mean.
No, I'd like to have been two or three people.
and I can put one of them over in research and one of them teaching and one of them reading up in research and so on, work in the library, references over.
You just don't, you can't spread yourself out unless you have an elaborate personnel.
You're not gonna do much in the way of research.
If it's all up to you and you have to teach too, you have nobody to help you, you might as well forget your research.
I still feel that.
Unless you have adequate help, your research isn't going to be worth a continental.
Well, you won't be able to produce anything in a lifetime.
As far as accomplishments, then, on your career, could you sum that up for me?
No, I'd have to be satisfied with what I did, but I just didn't feel that I did enough.
I wasn't physically capable or mentally either, I guess, to do more.
I did all I could for veterinary medicine and that was it.
And I think I've been appreciated.
I think my students appreciated me.
I think the wall in that room of yours demonstrates that.
Well, what I was after was turnout solid veterinarians.
I tell my students, you go out and practice, and if you don't know any more about diseases than the vocational ag teacher or the county agent, you're not going to be worth your salt.
He can see from his eyes out.
He can tell you that that's hog collar or that's black legs.
He knows the signs.
But can he think in terms of that disease?
What is happening in that animal's body?
What is happening within the cell?
What can you do to
Stop this disease in that cell.
What medicines are you going to give?
What is the interaction of the medicine with the disease process?
That's something that your county agent and your vocational ag man won't be able to solve.
He knows what he has.
But what's taking place, and that's what I want you to be capable of.

I want you to be able to take it down even to the chemistry or even into the electron microscope, into the small particles that are within the cytoplasm of the cell or within the little particle that's in the cytoplasm of the cell.
I want you to be able to see all the way through, not just from your nose out.
And unless you do, you're just a plain old quack.
That's it.
And I did everything I could to get anatomy over, especially microscopic anatomy.
The gross anatomy to me didn't matter very much.
But the microscopic did, because this is where
Everything works down in that cell.
And I said, unless you know your normal tissues, you're not going to have a basis to build the abnormals on.
That's just like the little girl in histology in medical school.
When we finished the course in histology, there were two or three abnormal slides of lung tissue.
She looked at those.
Of course, pathologic.
She didn't know what she was looking at.
But she had completed a course in normal cell study, histology.
She should have recognized lung and that there was something wrong with it.
She called the professor and said, I don't know what's wrong with this lung.
It's labeled abnormal.
It has holes in it, just like that other lung I looked at.
I thought, you poor thing.
If that is all that you have gotten out of a course in histology, you may as well not have taken it.
It has holes in it.
This was a section of lung that showed chronic passive congestion.
The alveolar walls were three or four times as thick as they normally should be.
There was emphysema.
Some of the spaces were many times, 20 times the size that they should be, and those walls were stretched thin.
There were heart lesion cells, phagocytic cells that had picked up blood pigment in the alveolar spaces.
She didn't see it.
This was lung because it had holes in it.
And that's all she had to build on in her pathology.
And I said, I surely would hate to be your pathology instructor, because you have nothing to build on.
In my way of teaching histology, they had as much pathology as they had histology.
We showed them the normal.
And then we compared it with abnormalities.
I didn't have to name the abnormality.
If it was low bar pneumonia or adenocarcinoma of the liver or just a plain old cirrhosis of the liver or pancreas or what are you, kidneys or what?
My training in pathology allowed me to show him the normal and impress on him
what that normal is.
And it had better be this way or else it's pathologic.
That's right.
So that was my idea of teaching histology.
I wouldn't give you a dime for a pure little course in histology.
And I've told them that over in biology.
And they don't like me.
They don't like you because you don't like them.
The old boy we had here teaching pathology when I was in anatomy, he didn't like it because I was carrying them off into pathology and comparing the normal and the abnormal.
To me, that's the way I wanted to be taught.
And that's the way I taught.
I taught it as I wanted to be taught, but was not.
That's the only way you're going to get it.
When you have somebody who's dedicated enough and is educated enough in that field, and he should be, if he's going to teach it, he should spend every waking hour improving himself in his field.
You're in history, and unless you stay with it and you burn your midnight oil and keep up with it and delve into it, you won't amount to a pinch either.
And unless you want to give it to your students, you're interested enough in them to want to give them everything that you can.
You don't have time for research.
You have to give them what is known at the present time.
And I mean, it had better be.
I don't have any meetings.
In anatomy, American Association of American Veterinary Anatomists.
And the last one I attended, here's an old boy from Colorado.
He loves to draw.
So in histology, what do they do?
They draw pictures they're looking at in the microscope.
Beautiful pictures of whatever organ it happens to be.
I said, well, when I was down in Galveston in 1950, they required me to take their freshman course in histology, which was, to me, a laugh.
Because I'd taught this stuff for 30 years.
And I'd had all the pathology.
And they weren't telling me anything about histology.
But we had to draw.
Because Dr. Pomerant was the instructor in histology.
And he is an artist.
in his own right, as well as an architect.
He was an architect.
He was an artist.
He had his PhD in science and tissue culture work.
Dr. Pomerant, he's dead now.
But he wanted us to make drawings.
And I said, I don't know how many hours I've spent just stippling.
I said, what do you learn when you stipple?
What do you learn when you spend all this time drawing?
I said, now, if that's all I have to teach in histology, I am not teaching.
I want to keep that student so busy looking at tissues he doesn't have time to draw, and I'm teaching him to recognize the normal.
And I'm comparing it with all kinds of abnormalities that I can find in that organ.
He's seen the whole work.
My kid said, Dr. John, I learned more pathology in your class than I did when I went to pathology.
I said, but you knew the normal.
Absolutely.
You know what's normal.
So that's the way.
But you don't have time for a lot of research.
Well, I'm glad that we can end this interview on such a strong note.
Well, I'll feel like that to my dying day.
Unless an instructor is heart and soul in it, and he has the student,

in the proper perspective this youngster has to get everything that i can put between his ears everything i'm not going to slight him in any way unless he has that attitude he better not be in teaching we have too damn many graduate students now who are working in there and all they want their degree and get gone

and you have more complaints about students they have a graduate assistant teaching a major course they may be a foreigner and they can't understand him half he says that anyhow we've had those complaints well thank you very much
This ends the interview with Dr. John Miller.
Well, Terry, I don't know where you are.
Appreciate it.
